docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled that an Indiana law requiring women to get counseling in person 18 hours before having an abortion is constitutional, reversing a lower court's decision. Opponents had argued that the law forced women to make two trips to a clinic before they could get an abortion, which could deter them from ending a pregnancy, and last year Judge David Hamilton of Federal District Court in Indianapolis struck down that provision. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, in a 2-to-1 ruling, said women did not face an unlawful obstacle in visiting a clinic twice, in part because the law had an emergency clause to cover physical or psychological risk to the woman.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Abortion Counseling Law Is Upheld

docs.abstract: Indiana federal appeals court reverses lower court decision, ruling that state law requiring women to obtain counseling in person 18 hours before having abortion is constitutional (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Women Seek Choices When Fibroid Tumors Strike'' (Aug. 27): A year after the birth of my first child, in 1964, a symptomatic fibroid tumor was diagnosed along the outside wall of my uterus. Fortunately, my ob-gyn had been trained in England. He did a myomectomy, leaving my uterus intact, explaining that this was a common procedure in Britain, although not known much in this country.
docs.abstract: Marcia Feingold letter on August 27 article praises gynecologist trained in England for performing myomectomy on fibroid tumor, which left her uterus intact
